results.title: The Memory of Water (part 1)
results.credit_line: Video excerpt and still images on this page are provided courtesy of the artist.
results.brief_description:
The ‘Memory of Water (part 1)’ explores Carl Jung’s notion of the ‘collective unconscious’, examining consciousness in the form of memory or perceived experience and the power of the gaze as that which mediates external phenomena. Sadia’s video explores the relationship between the drop and the ocean in terms of human experience. While the camera is trained in close up on their eyes, a series of people answer the question, “What is your most significant memory?”

The words and the eyes are played out of sync, so that one person’s voice speaks under another’s gaze. This simple device releases the memories from individual ownership, and the work becomes a gesture towards transcendence. Informed by the Jungian notion of the collective unconscious, The Memory of Water examines the gaze as a bridge between inner and outer worlds.

results.title: Liquid Sun (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Apace Research and Sydney University Television Services
results.brief_description: The production of power alcohol from farm crops, and its uses as motor fuel is causing great interest in Australia. It is a major challenge facing primary producers and could be an economic proposition in many areas

results.title: Half and Half
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “School’s Out”.
Prejudice, language and cultural differences are among the difficulties faced in school by migrant children. After school the problems are more pronounced: they feel halfway between their parents’ culture and the Australian lifestyle

results.title: You Just Don't Realise
results.creator_credit: Philippe de Montignie and Eyewitness News
results.brief_description: In Australia, where there is one vehicle for every three people, road accidents have reached epidemic proportions with 4,000 people dying each year. The trauma of the accidents themselves is only eclipsed by the trauma of the chain of events that follow. Highly graphic scenes of car accidents in this film make viewing unsuitable for sensitive people, and preview is strongly recommended

results.title: TERROR NULLIUS
results.brief_description: Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

constellations_other.name: Joy of drag
constellations_other.description: The Adventures of Priscilla, Queen of the Desert is a groundbreaking Australian film with a small budget and big impact that's taken queer Australian stories to the world.

constellations_other.name: Copy, transform and combine
constellations_other.description: You will see me (2020) repurposes material sourced from the history of the moving image – archival footage, news, interviews, documentaries, reality TV, video diaries and social media – to reflect on the way we perform in front of and reveal ourselves to the camera.

constellations_other.name: Remix and resistance (Since I left you)
constellations_other.description: The Avalanches' music videos are part of a long artistic tradition of reappropriation as a means of reframing perception.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

Equal parts political satire, eco-horror and road movie, TERROR NULLIUS is a rogue remapping of national mythology, where a misogynistic remark is met with the sharp beak of a bird, feminist bike gangs rampage and bicentenary celebrations are ravaged by flesh-eating sheep.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.
description_for_label:
Hitch a ride into the dark heart of Australia with Soda_Jerk’s TERROR NULLIUS, a blistering, badly behaved sample-based film that confronts the horror of our contemporary moment.

By intricately remixing fragments of Australia’s pop culture and film legacy, TERROR NULLIUS interrogates the unstable entanglement of fiction that underpins this country’s vexed sense of self.

Following the success of The Was, their 2016 collaboration with The Avalanches, Soda_Jerk return with a work that’s dark, hopeful, irreverent and urgent.

production_dates.notes: Commissioned and exhibited at ACMI for the first time March 20 2018

results.title: Technology/transformation: Wonder Woman
results.brief_description: ‘Technology/Transformation: Wonder Woman’ is an incendiary deconstruction of the ideology embedded in television and pop cultural iconography. Through radical manipulation of the female pop icon, Wonder Woman, Birnbaum subverts and reshapes its meaning within the television text.

results.title: [The funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey]
results.brief_description:
This film contains documentary footage of the state funeral of Field Marshal Sir Thomas Blamey, which took place on 30 May, 1951 in Melbourne, Victoria.

The film captures the funeral cortege as it proceeds along Swanston Street, with crowds of people lining the streets and buildings. The flag-covered casket is accompanied by a military band, soldiers and dignitaries. Significant public figures marching in the cortege include Prime Minister Robert Menzies, Governor-General William McKell, Governor of Victoria Sir Dallas Brooks and Chief Justice of the High Court Sir John Latham.

The film includes wonderful footage of Swanston Street from a high vantage point with the Shrine of Remembrance in the distance. There are also great shots of soldiers marching together, military horses, people gathered in front of the Melbourne City Baths and a couple watching on atop the facade of the ‘W.H. Terry Memorial Hall’.

An estimated 300,000 people turned out to watch the funeral procession, which travelled from the Shrine of Remembrance, along St Kilda Road, and up Swanston Street to College Crescent, before proceeding by car to Fawkner Crematorium.

Sir Thomas Blamey (24 Jan 1884 – 27 May 1951) was a General in the Australian army and the only Australian to have achieved the rank of Field Marshal.

results.title: Supervising women workers
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A factory foreman discusses with the supervisor the “problem” of supervising women workers in his department. The fact is brought out that the same rules apply in supervising both men and women; but, “as women often have not had as much industrial experience as men, and in most cases have more home responsibilities than men, these factors must be taken into account”. Note that this film was made in 1944 and uses such terms as “breaking in” the female workers and “the eternal feminine”. Interesting from a historical point of view.

results.title: A Place to live
results.creator_credit: Stuart Glover, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy
results.brief_description: Story of immigration and discussion of how newcomers look for houses, units or commission housing on offer in the city. Immigration officers help migrants get loans and settle in ‘suburbia’, the ideal for many migrants.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stuart Glover, Frank Bagnall, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Film Academy
